jkl; respectfully, you are buying into the writer's game of three card monte. A limit on deductibility is not a raise in tax rates. And medicare taxes are paid half by employees and half by employers, the writer attributes all to the employee.

If you add the employer's share to the employee, it looks like the total tax rate is higher, but the honest analyst would add this amount to income as well.

Finally, these are discussions about marginal rates on 'wages.' When your station in life is such that your 'wage' hits $450,000, you are likely to have significant income in interest, dividends, capital gains, etc. And your total tax rate is far lower than the amounts bandied about by the pro-rich who call themselves pro-growth.

Are you also taking the sole breadwinner subsidies? If so, you need to pay more taxes - or receive reduced benefits - than you currently do.

The average sole breadwinner takes 3:1 out of the Social Security and Medicare system.

In contrast, 2-earner/2-parent families and singles pay their own way.

Paul, you and I probably have more in common than you might think, but you are wrong about the Pease limitation. While it was purportedly designed as a cap on deductions, it actually functions as a tax on income above $250,000 for a married couple. Go ahead and read the statute and work the algebra, you'll see what I mean.

Your numbers are nonsense.  The top rate is not 45%, it is 39.8, and given the lower rate for gains and dividends the effective rate is even less. Moreover, and as opposed to 1935, those of us at the cap live about five years longer than those nearer and below the median.  We get bigger social security checks, and we get  an average of 30% more of them since we live longer.  A 30% hike on the income ceiling is justified on its face.

To whatsinchicago:

Federal spending is NOT in the 20% range -- if it were, we wouldn't have a lot of diagreements. In fact, but for the sequester, it still would be in the 24%-range under Mr. Obama, and has been well above the historic norm of 19% since he assumed office, and way above the 20% most Republicans target. And his dead-on-arrival budget calls for spending to be in the 22% range for years into the future.

The regulatory environment and the tax environment, after adjustments to the AMT exclusions and the sunsetting of the sunsetting of the Clinton tax increases effected at the start of this calendar year, certainly are NOT what they were prior to the crash -- they're substantially more onerous than they were under a president who has repeatedly made clear that he will bypass a frozen Congress to impose his values wherever he can -- and he has immense power to direct the non-independent regulatory agencies to impose mostly environmental but other types of regulation, as well, as he sees fit.

And it gets worse. Sec. Sibelius is only starting to make excuses for why ObamaCare isn't working and will require even greater subsidies than projected -- and this for a program that was supposed to save money that we don't have, not eat up more of it.

Mr. Luettgen, I'm rather confused by your pronouncements that Bernanke has done nothing to force capital into risk assets. How have you missed the zero interest rate, the unprecedented bond buying binges, and every other form of market manipulation employed by the Fed? Now we have grossly overvalued equity markets as retirees have been forced into entirely unsuitable investments in order to earn some sort of return on their savings. This has served the sole purpose of delaying the inevitable deleveraging cycle, and making that deleveraging all the more painful.

And there is absolutely no evidence to suggest that the government should be devoting even more public spending to investing in private businesses. We continue to hear about Green Energy bankruptcies on a regular basis because that is the inevitable result of the government fighting market forces. Businesses that aren't viable don't need to be propped up by the US government.

The best thing Obama could do for the US economy would be to stop adding new regulations, stop attacking employers, and get out of the way of private business. But, given his complete lack of business experience or background, I expect him to continue to meddle in a detrimental manner.

RT:

I thought I'd explained Bernanke's failure to drive capital into useful pursuits with zero-interest rates in one of my responses to whatsinchicago. In an environment as chancy as ours, in which nobody really knows where regulatory and tax policy is going to go, business, that holds much of that capital, has no rational basis for expanding, merely for improving profits by bearing down on productivity. That's basically what's happening.

Add to that Mr. Obama's ill-advised insistence on increasing capital gains taxes, which further reduces the incentive for capital to put itself at risk, it's not surprising that capital prefers a no-risk proposition until things become clearer and perhaps more incentivizing -- even at the zero-or-negative returns T-bills offer.

Capital is by its nature conservative; and one doesn't need to be wildly risk-averse to be VERY cautious about today's political environment.

People might cite lack of demand as a contributing factor, and no doubt it is, but demand doesn't just happen -- despte what B-school managers seem to think. And it's not even a chicken-or-egg question: It happens when a steady of supply of new goods and services causes people to want to make sacrifices to buy. But to generate that steady supply requires the capital parked in zero-risk T-bills our government so conveniently makes available to fund our monstrous deficits.

Where did you ever get the idea I was suggesting that government invest in private businesses? Eeeeech.

My comments to Edsall pieces are never so much responses but exercises in clarifying my own thinking on the themes he parses -- not the easiest thing at midnight with a glass of bourbon beckoning; but, like occasionally responding to Larry Eisenberg in verse, a duty, nonetheless.

Mr. Obama could do what he could do but chooses not to do, for his own reasons.

We will need to concoct wholly new and alien social organizational schemes to deal with billions of human beings who cannot productively contribute to the economies that are rapidly developing, yet still need somehow to subsist. We're only at the beginning of the process of thinking about what those schemes might be. But short of imposing global command economies that make places perforce for repetitive-task jobs, governments can do little to halt the process. What they can do is give us time to better think through the strategic approaches that will be needed to manage the future. How might that be done?

Spend less. Force capital not into T-bills to fund deficits but out to fund start-ups and expansions, that would create new goods and services that people want to buy more than they want to retire personal debt. Demand goes up, people are hired to build and maintain inventories, and we push the sun back into the sky for a few more hours. And while it's still shining, we figure out what to do to keep the darkness from extinguishing all light.

That's what the president could do: but he shows no interest in doing it.

And lets not bury the lead. It's no coincidence that R&R chose the only issue that isn't peer reviewed to unveil their flimsy study, now is it?  I'm a lawyer (who majored in Econ undergrad). I don't believe in any coincidence THAT big.

It is clearly stated on the cover page of the R-R paper that it is a working paper and that "NBER working papers are circulated for discussion and comment purposes. They have not been peer- reviewed or been subject to the review by the NBER Board of Directors that accompanies official NBER publications."
It is further stated on the NBER website that "NBER Working Papers ... are intended to make results of NBER research available to other economists in preliminary form to encourage discussion and suggestions for revision before publication."
So it is obvious to anyone who looks into the matter that the paper was originally presented as not being in final form and was not really "published" (making me wonder how many of the people who quoted it actually looked at it). Nevertheless, it was treated as a formally published paper by those who liked the results and by the authors themselves once they got favorable press. This is not just sloppy data handling and questionable weightings, it is a misrepresentation of the paper itself as being a formal publication rather than a preliminary draft.

The RR paper in question here was not peer reviewed. It was published in the annual Papers and Proceedings issue of the American Economic Review. Other issues of the AER are peer reviewed, but the P&P issue features invited papers and conference proceedings that have not passed through the standard process.
